en: Interview with Fran Day, 2020-01-11

Interview with Fran Day of Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts. Day provides a history of the school in the area and its role in the community. She then discusses her experience leading up to and during the fire. She also talks about how Arrowmont was active in the community following the wildfires. This is a representative quote from the interview: "There's some tenets in our culture: you never take without giving back, you have a certain responsibility to your neighbor, you don't whine, you don't what you can when you can, and you just deal with whatever comes."

motion pictures (visual works)

Interview with Fran Day of Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts. Day provides a history of the school in the area and its role in the community. She then discusses her experience leading up to and during the fire. She also talks about how Arrowmont was active in the community following the wildfires. This is a representative quote from the interview: "There's some tenets in our culture: you never take without giving back, you have a certain responsibility to your neighbor, you don't whine, you don't what you can when you can, and you just deal with whatever comes."

Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Fran Day, 2020-01-11
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and tell us a little about yourself?
Can you tell me a little about the Arrowmont School of Arts and Crafts?
Can you tell me about the Arrowmont School as it exists today in the community?
Tell me about how Arrowmont is situated in what is very much an arts community.
Can you tell us about the days and weeks leading up to the 2016 wildfires?
About what time of day is this that you're setting up for Souper Bowl?
What part of town did you live in?
It sounds like you were composed while making these decisions, what were you feeling at this point?
Was your husband at the Rocky Top community center?
Do you remember what news station initially reported that Arrowmont had burned?
When you met with your colleagues again, did they know if their homes had survived or not?
What was it like going into Gatlinburg for the first time after the fire?
Have you noticed an emotional toll that the event has had on you?
From your anthropological perspective, can you talk about the human element during this event?
Do you think that this could happen again in East Tennessee?
Is there anything else good that came out of this disaster?
Can you share with us the value of sharing your story an dpreserving it?
What do you think the lessons learned are?
